toLevel3.question: Why does the first shell only hold 2 electrons while the second holds 8?

toLevel3.question: Explain why the electron configuration of potassium (19 electrons) is 2, 8, 8, 1 and not 2, 8, 9.

distractors.explanation: It is not about the fourth needing electrons; it is about 4s being lower energy than 3d.

toLevel3.question: Argon has 18 electrons with configuration 2, 8, 8. Explain why argon is stable even though its third shell is not at full capacity (18).

toLevel5.correctExplanation: Period 1 (2 elements: 1s²), Periods 2-3 (8 elements: s²p⁶), Periods 4-5 (18 elements: s²d¹⁰p⁶), and Period 6 (32 elements: s²f¹⁴d¹⁰p⁶). Shell capacities directly shape the table.

toLevel5.question: Chromium has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹ instead of the expected [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s². Analyse why half-filled subshells provide extra stability.

toLevel5.correctExplanation: When each of the five 3d orbitals has exactly one electron (all with parallel spins), the exchange energy is maximised, providing extra stability. This causes an electron to 'promote' from 4s to 3d.

distractors.answer: Chromium is an exception due to an error in measurement
distractors.explanation: Chromium's configuration is well-confirmed and explained by exchange energy.

distractors.answer: Half-filled subshells are less stable, which makes chromium more reactive
distractors.explanation: Half-filled subshells are more stable, not less.

distractors.answer: 4s always has exactly 1 electron for all transition metals

toLevel5.question: Why do Periods 4 and 5 each contain 18 elements, while Periods 2 and 3 only contain 8?

distractors.answer: The third shell suddenly gains 10 extra capacity in Period 4

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the 2n² rule gives maximum capacities of 2, 8, 18, 32 and relate this to the quantum numbers.

distractors.answer: Each shell adds exactly 10 more electrons than the previous

distractors.answer: No model can predict electron configurations

toLevel5.correctExplanation: Half-filled (d⁵) and fully-filled (d¹⁰) subshells have extra stability due to exchange energy. Both Cr and Cu sacrifice a 4s electron to achieve these configurations.
